person.bibl: Amit, “Inscribed and Stamped Ring Stands,” no. 6
person.note: On the form הורקנוס see vol. 1, under Hyrcanus (3) P/M. p. 350. On the fall of the ו vowel see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
On the form פרוך see vol. 4, under Farruχ (1) I/M. p. 175. On the fall of the ו vowel see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13.
The son is desiganted ביר, which probably stands forבר ר' (Rabbi x’s son).
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

The text goes: אבא שאול בר אנש ואמרי לה אבא שאול בר רמש. This form is found in the second instance in the printed edition and in Ms Vatican 113, in the third instance in Ms Munich 95. This form was obviously unknown to the scribes, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4.
See previous note. So in Ms Munich 95 in the second instance.

See above n. 2. The text goes: אבא שאול בר אנש ואמרי לה אבא שאול בר רמש. This form is found in the second instance in the printed edition and in Ms Vatican 113, in the third instance in Ms Munich 95. This form was obviously unknown to the scribes, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. So in the second instance, in Ms Vatican 111.

See above n. 2. The text goes: אבא שאול בר אנש ואמרי לה אבא שאול בר רמש. This form is found in the second instance in the printed edition and in Ms Vatican 113, in the third instance in Ms Munich 95. This form was obviously unknown to the scribes, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. So in the first instance, in Ms Vatican 113.

See above n. 2. The text goes: אבא שאול בר אנש ואמרי לה אבא שאול בר רמש. This form is found in the second instance in the printed edition and in Ms Vatican 113, in the third instance in Ms Munich 95. This form was obviously unknown to the scribes, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. So in the first instance, in the printed edition.

See above n. 2. The text goes: אבא שאול בר אנש ואמרי לה אבא שאול בר רמש. This form is found in the second instance in the printed edition and in Ms Vatican 113, in the third instance in Ms Munich 95. This form was obviously unknown to the scribes, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. So in the second instance, in Ms Bologna Archivio di Stato Fr. ebr. 195.
This is Saul (1) in the Addendum to vol. 1, p. 449, but there I did not take his father’s name as a personal name, but rather as a location. I suggest this interpretation here.
Although this is the only tradition in which he is mentioned and it is in BT, Designated רבי, it is in Hebrew and in the form of a tannaitic tradition.
See previous note and vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.7, p. 52.
This form is not recorded elswhere, but it looks like the Semitic אבון with a Greek genetive declension. On the form אבון see under Abbin (5) S-H/M in this volume.
West of Hebron.

Jewishness may be suggested based on Semitic name, and on the fact that Beth Govrin boasted a large Jews community in the Roman period, but both are inconclusive, see Introduction 6.2.1.6, and vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.1, p. 50.

person.bibl: Solomon of Basra,Book of the Bee, 123
person.note: In Syriac, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read אדי. On this form see vol. 4, under Ada (35) S-H/M, p. 327.
In Syriac – ܡܢ ܦܢܝܣ.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
This composition describes the time shortly after Jesus’ death, see vol. 1, Introduction 5.6., p. 42.
Appears always transmitting a certain tannaitic tradition (תני).
See bErub 37b.
See above, n. 2, Appears always transmitting a certain tannaitic tradition (תני). and vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
This would be a fitting transliteration of this name, see previous note and LXX for other names of this sort, e.g. for אחיהוד in 1 Chr 26:7 (̓Αχιούδ).
On the persons in this genealogical list and how they are dated see Introduction 8.1.2.3.
See previous note.
The inscription was found in the remains of the destroyed Samaritan Temple, see Introduction 8.1.1.1.
See previous note. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1 of the destruction of the Samaritan Temple.
So in bHul 11b. On the fall of the י vowel see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, pp. 13-4.
Although mentioned only in BT, Described as transmitting tannaitic traditions, in all the sources in which he is mentioned, see vol. 1, Introduction 5.7.2, pp. 42-3.

In this source (and in bHul 11b and bHul 52b) Designated so, as if it were his name, but elsewhere this is a title, see above, n. 1. This is a title, see Introduction 3.1.1. This could be an important sage who is so designated as Rabbi Judah the Patriarch (Judah [36] B/M in vol.1, p. 113) is designated “Rabbi” or Abba Arikh (Abba [70] S-H/M, in vol. 4, p. 311) is designated “Rav,” but no such important sage is known from elsewhere.
On this date see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. For this form in Greek and Latin see vol. 1, under Gira (1) S/H/M, p. 368.
Perhaps to be identified with the rebel leader.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
On the fall of the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.6.2, p. 29.
On the dating of documents from Qumran see vol. 1, Introduction 7.7.2, p. 54.
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read הודמכה.
This is the Samaritan version of the story of the translation of the Torah into Greek. The Samritans name four scholars and mention many others with them, but do not mention the number 70.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
Was active under Ptolemy Philadelphus. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
On such nicknames, see vol. 1, Appendix – Ha Names, pp. 445-8.
For dating of finds from Masada see vol. 1, Introduction 7.8, p. 54.

On the form ̓Αββιβος see vol. 3, under Habub (2) S-H/M, p. 670. This seems to be an almost identical form in Latin, except for tha case ending. This suggests that the Greek form represent the Semitic form חביב without a suffix and this form represents the Semitic form חביבא with the typical Aramaic suffix.
This is Gameliel (1) B/M, in vol.1, p. 85.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
For such dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.3, p. 51.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Honi (13) S-H/M, p. 377.
The inscription was found in the remains of the destroyed Samaritan Temple, see Introduction 8.1.1.1.
See previous note. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1 of the destruction of the Samaritan Temple.

state.note: Inscription, City of David, E. Mazar

person.note: On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
On this form see vol. 1, under Honi (16) S-H/M, p. 377.
On the dating of documents from Qumran see vol. 1, Introduction 7.7.2, p. 54.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Honi (13) S-H/M, p. 377.

person.note: The editor dates the ostraca from Maresha to before the Bar Kokhba Revolt, which was quenched in this year.
On this form see vol. 1, under Onias (20) S-H/M, p. 377, and vol. 3, under Onias (8) S-H/M, p. 671.
The papyrus was composed in Palestine. If it mentions biblical names at such a date it is Jewish, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52
The papyrus is dated according to the year in which Zenon visited Palestine.
On this form see vol. 4, under Ḥiyya (27) S-H/M, pp. 360-1.
On the Tomb of the Prophet on the Mount of Olives and the character of the inscriptions read there see Introduction 8.1.2.1.
If the Tomb of the Prophets was a Jewish site, (see previous note) it had to have been in use before the destruction of the Temple, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
For this form see in this volume under Ḥalifa (24) S-H/M.
This is Herod (1) G/M, in vol. 1, p. 282.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
The event described here is associated with the death of John the Baptist. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1.
For this form see in this volume under Ḥalifa (11) S-H/M.
In the Golan Heights.
The region of the Golan was peopled by many non-Jews and there are no Jewish markers on this stone, see Introduction 6.2.1.3.
Inscription dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.
In Transjordan in the Jordan Valley.
The editors claim the sherd comes from a Hellenistic layer but concedes that finds from this layer are mixed with earlier ones from the Persian period.
In Transjordan.

There is every reason to assume that this settlement was Jewish, since the ostraca were found in the vicinity of a seal mentioning the Jewish province of יהד in the Persian period, but this vicinity also makes it possible to date this ostracon to the Persian period.
On the dating of documents from Qumran see vol. 1, Introduction 7.7.2, p. 54.

person.floruit: Of the seventy disciples of Jesus
person.note: So in the Arabic version, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read מארי. On the additional א see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3.1, p. 13.
So in the Syriac version, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read מארי, see previous note.
In Arabic – احد المرسومين من السبعين. In Syriac – ܫܠܝܚܐ ܚܕ ܡܢ ܫܒܥܝܢ (see p. 2).

Even though this composition describes his Christianizing activities in Mesopotamia, he is a disciple of Jesus, and thus of Palestinian provenance. Described in the Arabic text as عبراني (Hebrew), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.2, p. 29.
See previous note.

person.bibl: Solomon of Basra,Book of the Bee, 106
person.note: In Syriac, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read ברנבא. On this form in Greek see vol. 3, under Nabaius (1) S-G/M, p. 699.
Appears in a list following the words ܢܛܘܵܪܐ ܕܝܢ ܕܩܒܘܪܬܐ ܚܡܫܐ ܐܝܬܝܗܘܢ ܗܘܘ ܘܗܠܝܢ ܫܡܗܵܝܗܘܢ (Guards of the tomb were five and these are their names:).
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
Mentioned in association with Jesus’ crucifixion. This is its date, see Introduction 7.1.

All versions (including נהוראי) are found in the mss, see Theodor-Albeck, Bereschit Rabba, 1133. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12.
See previous note. On the fall of the ו as a dialect difference see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 11.

See above, n. 2. All versions (including נהוראי) are found in the mss, see Theodor-Albeck, Bereschit Rabba, 1133. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. On the fall of the ו and א as a dialect phenomenon see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13.

See above, n. 2. All versions (including נהוראי) are found in the mss, see Theodor-Albeck, Bereschit Rabba, 1133. This person was obviously not well known, and his name was not stable so that the scribes of the mss were not sure how to write it, see vol. 4, Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, pp. 23-4. On the double י as a consonant see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.4.3, p. 12. This may be a scribal “correction” identifying this person with Sura in Mesopotamia (which is obviously false), see vol. 4, Introduction 2.7.2, p. 18.
In Aramaic – אבה/אבא.
Was a contemporary of Tryphon (4) in vol. 1, p. 308, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In Arabic, see Introduction 2.5.2. In Hebrew this would read סומלה.
This is the Samaritan version of the story of the translation of the Torah into Greek. The Samritans name four scholars and mention many others with them, but do not mention the number 70.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
Was active under Ptolemy Philadelphus. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
On the fall of the vowels see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.6, p. 13.
In Transjoradn, in the Jordan Valley.
The editors claim the sherd comes from a Hellenistic layer but concedes that finds from this layer are mixed with earlier ones from the Persian period.
Appears three times in BT (bSuk33a, 36a, bNaz 51b) and in all three he transmits a tradition after the tannaitic signifier תני, and in Hebrew, see vol. 1, Introduction 5.7.2, pp. 42-3.
See previous note. On this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
The inscription was found in the remains of the destroyed Samaritan Temple, see Introduction 8.1.1.1.
See previous note. This is the date, see Introduction 7.1 of the destruction of the Samaritan Temple.
This is Dositheus (7) G/M in vol. 1, p. 274. On the use of Samaritan chronicles in this volume see Introduction 512.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
On this date see vol. 1, p. 275, n. 13.
In the printed edition Designated יוסי בן יוסי בן פרורה, but in the Leiden Ms only יוסי בן פירורה.
He is a contemporary of Rabbi Eliezer (Eleazar [39] in vol. 1, p. 66), see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.2, p. 52.
On the dating of documents from Qumran see vol. 1, Introduction 7.7.2, p. 54.
Reconstructed by CIIP editors. For the form שולי see vol. 1, under Shulai (1) S-H/M. p. 413. On the additional א see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.3.1, p. 13.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
On this form see vol. 1, under Shatia (1) S-H/M, p. 414.
On the dating of documentary papyri from the Judaean Desert see vol. 1, Introduction 7.7, p. 53.
In Hebrew – מפט[רה].

The ostracon was probably a list of names with places of origin, one of them Jerusalem, where the ostracon was found. It was written in Hebrew, probably by a Jew, but this person has a Nabatean name and his place of origin is the Nabatean capital. Since we do not know what purpose the ostracon served, the nationality of this person must remain obscure.
On the dating of finds from Jerusalem see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.2, p. 52.
Designated תדל בר.
Although mentioned only in BT, this is a baraita, see Introduction 5.1.3.2.7.
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
A contemporary of Rabbi Meir, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.3, p. 52.
On this form see vol. 1, under Toma (1) S-H/M, p. 416.
In Greek – ̓Ισραηλίτου φιλοσόφου. This description casts doubt on a possible identification of this person with Toma (1) S-H/M, in vol. 1, p. 416, who was an apostle and no philosopher.
This is a Christian apocryphal composition, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.2.2, p. 48.
If he is Jesus’ disciple, this would be his date. If not, it is impossible to date him.
So in the parallel version in Krauss, Leben Jesu, p. 81. On this form see Tanḥum (2) S-H/M in this volume. In Krauss, Leben Jesu, p. 129 the version is תנחום.
Described in the text as ר'.
See Introduction to Addendum.
The event takes place in the year Jesus is crucified, see Introduction 7.1.
For this dating see vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

div.note: The name is derived from a region in Persia (WGE, 1585-6). Justi, INB, 133, mentions an Arsakid king by the name of ̔Υρκώδης. In Justi, ibid. 355-6, he mentions “Warkaina” as a proper name, probably of the same root.
In Justi, INB, 94-8, the name Farruχan is presented. It means “possessing divine grace,” see Introduction 1.4.
Persian, Justi, INB, 258.

אבא means “father” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2). For the Aramaic name see Lipiński, Studies 1, 190-4. אבא is documented on a First Temple Hebrew seal (CWSSS no. 44); in 3rd C BCE Egypt (TADAE 4, 8:11); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 8); for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 23, no. 2) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 1).

אב means “father” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1-2). ’BN is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 16) and ’BYN Palmyrene (Stark, PNPI, 1). On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.
אדי means “to swing, throw, pitch” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 16). It is recorded on an Aramaic, Persian-period seal (CWSSSno. 759); and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 65).
The form ’Y is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 87).
The name is otherwise unknown, but the biblical names אחיהוד (Num 34:27); אביהוד (1 Chr 8:3) and עמיהוד (e.g. Num 1:3) are well known. This seems like a very reasonable similar name.
The name אצלח is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 139. The form ’ṢLḤ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 52).
This is a title, see Introduction 3.1.1.

גירא means “lime” or “arrow” or “direct consequence” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 241-2). JR is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 157). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. “Proselyte” is גיור or גיורי in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 236).

גלגלא means “wheel” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 245). A similar name is recorded from the First Temple period (EBTHPN, 39). גלגל and גלגול are recorded names in Elephantine (TADAE 2, 3.1; 4.1). גלגל is documented as an Idumean name (AOFCI, nos 200-1). JLJLN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 164).

גרף in Hebrew means “to scrape, sweep” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 272). The form גרפו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem32 (1991) no. 257; the form JRF is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 159.
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
קטף in Aramaic means “resin gained by tapping balsam” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1352).

The root חבב means “to love” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 415-7). חבובא/חיבובא means “beloved” (Jastrow, ibid. 450). ḤBWB is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 87). ḤBB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 172).
Neither this name nor any of its variants are mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, but they clearly belong to the family of biblical names such as יוחנן and חנניה.
חייא means “life” or “midwife” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 454). ḤYW is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 211). חיא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 429).

חלבון means “glare, white of an egg” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 464. The name חלבו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 442. The form ḤLB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 197).

חליפה means “replacement, substitution” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 469). This name is recorded in Palmyra (ḤLYP’, see Stark, PNPI, 88). ḤLF is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 198). The Nabateans used חליפו (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 448).
The name is obviously theophoric and Jewish, meaning (in Aramaic) “Yahu gave” but it is not recorded in the Hebrew Bible.
The name is obviously theophoric and Jewish, meaning “all for Yahu” but it is not recorded in the Hebrew Bible. On the other hand, the name כליון (meaning destruction) is recorded in Ruth 1:2.
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them.
מסבלי means “load” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 803-4). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4.Alternatively, Justi, INB, 198, records the Persian name Μασαβάτης.

מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). This name (MRY) is recorded on an Aramaic First Temple seal (CWSSSno. 808); and for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 542). The name מרי is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 691.

The root נבי/נבא means “burst forth, prophesy” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 868). נבי is recorded as a name on First Temple Hebrew seals, (CWSSSnos. 379, 530); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 580); in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 98).

נהורא means “eye-sight, light” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 881). נהירו and נהרו are recorded as names for Idumeans (AOFCI, nos. 57, 108, 175). נהר is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 601). נהרא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 99).
שמלה means “garment” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1596).
סכר means “maker of water-locks” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 993). The form SKR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 323).
סומקא means “red” in Aramaic (Jastrow DTTBYML, 966). SMK is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 329).
Palmyrene name (‘GYLW, see Stark, PNPI, 43-4).
עולא means “infant, nursling, child” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1050). The form ’LH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 432).
For some names no etymology or parallel was found. This is one of them. If this is the correct reading, it seems like some sort of onomatopeic nickname, perhaps imitating a bird.

פילפלא means “ball, grain, especially pepper” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1184). The name transliterated is probably פלפלה, see Introduction 2.1.2.1. For the form Φελφελα for a Samaritan woman see under Felfela (1) S-G/F in this volume.
פרירא/פרידא means “pebble” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1225, 1228). פירורא means “mush, crumble” in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 1171).
שוא as a name is recorded in 1 Chr 2:49. As such it is also recorded on a 5th century BCE graffito from Egypt (TADAE 4, 268). On the interchange of א and ה see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.1-2, p. 25.
The root שול in Hebrew “That which hangs on, attachment” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1534).
שטיא means “insane, madman, fool” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1553).
Nabatean name, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1123,
The name TD’L is recorded for a female in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 53).

תומא means “simplicity” or “garlic” or “fringe” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1654). T’M is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 127). The Nabatean name תאומא is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1193).

תנחומין means “consolation” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1681). The name תנחם is documented in Hebrew and Ammonite First Temple seals (CWSSS nos. 707-8, 947). Alternatively, Justi, INB, 322, records the Persian name “Tanhā.”
